Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Bowie State University Applied Biotechnology Initiatives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Bowie State University (BSU) seeks to use the platform of the existing collaboration between Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, BSU and Godfrey Okoye University (GOU) on DNA barcoding projects to infuse basic and advanced interdisciplinary biotechnology concepts and laboratory skills into its biology undergraduate degree program and to train students that are equipped to function as independent laboratory technicians and/or pursue postgraduate degrees in biotechnology/STEM. The Bowie State Applied Biotechnology Initiative (BSABI) builds on a previous NSF project that supported a genomics lab and a Biotechnology Summer Institute in the Natural Sciences Department.

The BSABI has three key objectives: a) Curriculum enhancement of the Molecular Biology (Biol 303) course, by infusing it with intensive research for discovery-based learning; b) Research infrastructure upgrade to support the curriculum redesign for hands-on research experience for students; and c) International research experience, to provide students opportunity to collect and categorize germplasm in their native environments. The project augments faculty capacity to instruct students through the provision of cutting edge equipment for research and teaching, and by infusing hands-on laboratory activities and undergraduate research projects into an existing molecular biology course. The DNA barcoding project enables BSU to respond to the growing demands for understanding and categorizing biodiversity. In perspective, besides training 160 minority students to join the STEM workforce, the broader impact of this project is to promote global exploration, biodiversity conservation and utilization of indigenous genetic resources.

The collaboration among Bowie State University (BSU), the DNA Learning Center at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (CSHL), NY, and (GOU), Nigeria, fosters a diversity of research experiences, both locally and internationally, for undergraduates in the Department of Natural Sciences at BSU. BSU uses the platform of this existing liaison on DNA barcoding projects among the three institutions to infuse basic and advanced interdisciplinary concepts and laboratory skills into its biology degree program. The ultimate goal is to create student driven class projects that answer pertinent biological questions while providing students with the opportunity to acquire basic but vital laboratory skills for concentration in biotechnology. The hands-on research experience built into the courses operates on an open-lab concept that is designed to promote peer-mentoring and provide students with independence to explore and be creative in their discovery-based learning experience.

Over the course of the three-year project, at least one hundred and sixty (160) underrepresented minority undergraduates will receive state of the art education and advanced training in molecular biology and biotechnology. An extensive evaluation process is incorporated into the project to monitor and measure program effectiveness. Outcomes of this project will be widely disseminated for the benefit of the academic community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bowie State Applied Biotechnology Initiative (BSABI), is a targeted infusion effort, aimed at enhancing the existing Molecular Biology (BIOL 303) course, develop and implement a new advanced Genetic Engineering course (BIOL 424), upgrade existing laboratory infrastructure, and promote collaborative international research experiences in undergraduate research.

Curriculum

  1. Molecular Biology (BIOL 303) was successfully converted into a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE), in which students engage in whole semester of research that address real-life problems of interest to the scientific community.  Over the past 5 academic years, 330 undergraduate students have benefited from the intensive hands-on research projects (including DNA Barcoding and Metagenomics projects) integrated into the Molecular Biology class. Currently, on average, 30 students register every semester, looking forward to being effectively prepared for the biotechnology and molecular biology workforce and postgraduate opportunities. CURE research projects have resulted in several posters and oral presentations at Bowie State University Research Expo, organized by the Office of Research and Sponsored Programs, BSU National Food Day, and national and international conferences.
  2. A new course, Genetic Engineering (BIOL 424) was created, reviewed, and approved by the University Curriculum Committee. BIOL 424 is designed to be project-based and provides students the opportunity to acquire advanced skills in the application of molecular biology techniques in research and in recombinant DNA technology. This course provides an overview of the basic principles of molecular biology and emphasizes their application in research, industry, and society in general.  An average of 15 students takes the class every semester and more than 150 students, mostly African Americans, have taken this hands-on research-intensive class.
  3. Biotechnology Minor: As a result of this funded program, we were able to develop courses, including Introduction to Biotechnology (4 credits), Applied Biotechnology (4 credits), and Genetic Engineering so that we were able to offer a 15 credit-load Minor in Biotechnology to our Biology Majors in the Department of Natural Sciences. The goal is to produce more minorities who can engage in the Biotechnology workforce. It is our desire to have a BS degree in Biotechnology and an MS in Applied Biotechnology and Molecular Biology. 

Research Infrastructure

Our lab has grown into a full-fledged plant genomics laboratory with food forensics capability and DNA fingerprinting technology for biodiversity and phylogenetic studies. We have purchased more advanced technologies for training and research in Biotechnology and Molecular Biology. Cohorts of faculty and students from other institutions often visit the genomics lab to use some of our equipment for basic and advanced molecular biology research. In 2017, the State of Maryland funded a new science building to expanded research capacity and laboratory experience for students.

International travel to expose students to research and multicultural interactive learning abroad

Six Bowie State University minority students travelled abroad to conduct real-life research at the Godfrey Okoye University, Enugu, Nigeria. Our students worked alongside Nigerian students who exposed their American counterparts to research and cultural traditions of Enugu State, Nigeria. Together, they travelled remote villages of Enugu state to collect local yam and fish samples for DNA barcoding research and partnered to conduct DNA extraction, PCR, agarose gel electrophoresis and sequencing and Bioinformatics data analysis using DNA Subway. Students enjoyed traditional food and music, paid visits to local statesmen, and visited national museums. The outcome of the joint research by undergrads from the two institutions were two peer-reviewed scientific journal articles.

Overall, the major accomplishment of this grant is in the broadening of undergraduate research culture in the Department of Natural Sciences. During the Fall 2014 semester, there was little or no undergraduate research. Pedagogy was centered around traditional lectures accompanied by cookbook laboratory exercises that lacked inquiry-based activity. This funding infused research and real-life scientific investigation into whole-semester projects for the entire cohort of Molecular Biology (BIOL 303) students. This new teaching method, now branded as CUREs, has truly revolutionized teaching and learning in the department. Both faculty and students were in awe at the impact undergraduate research was having on minority and underrepresented students' in their identity as scientists, retention, and graduation rates. 

This CURE experience has expanded our collaborations with PIs and Schools across the country. Since 2014, CURE has evolved into a cross-curricular model in which students can acquire basic research skills in ten unique research streams: DNA Barcoding, Cell Culture and Viability, Plant Metabolomics, Metagenomics, Antibiotic Resistance, Cellular Biology, Bioinformatics, Cancer Biology and Engineering, Genetic Engineering and Transcriptomics, and Drug Synthesis. These "Cross-Curricular CUREs,” funded by Bowie State University, now infuse research into the mandatory classes in our Biology, Chemistry, Bioinformatics and Science Education programs. Our department provides training to ensure sustainability and proper administration of undergraduate research in all classes and for the benefit of all students. As a consequence, our students are more confident in undertaking Ph.Ds, medicine, and other STEM jobs.
